texts.definition: Open locations in game worlds that naturally or by design become battlegrounds.
markups: <style="Definition">Open locations in game worlds that naturally or by design become battlegrounds.</style>

In games where combat occurs, the characteristics of gameplay locations can heavily influence how this can be done. <style="CurrentLink">Arenas</style> are open areas which draws players into conflicts there, either because they contain check points or resources or because players have willingly placed themselves within them to challenge others.

While maybe not a big surprise given its name, Quake III Arena contains many maps with Arenas, e.g. arena gate, dredwerks, and the forgotten place. Many of central access routes and check points in Team Fortress 2 maps are also Arenas, e.g. the areas attackers need to take in Dustbowl. Other First-Person Shooters that have Arenas include the Halo and the Unreal Tournament series. Given the open maps in America's Army and the Battlefield series, the games do not have clear Arenas but combat in these games are often located to specific areas anyway.
The Elder Scrolls series have explicit Arenas where players can earn money by fighting monsters or non-player characters in duels. This is also possible in the thorn in Fallout: New Vegas.

The prime requirement of creating <style="CurrentLink">Arenas</style> is to make sure there are open but constrained areas in <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>. However, for <style="CurrentLink">Arenas</style> to be perceivable as interesting structures in games, there needs to be other gameplay areas available as well (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> can be said to have <style="CurrentLink">Arenas</style> that consist of the entire boards but trying to use the pattern in this way offers little in the way of design options or for understanding the resulting gameplay). <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sniper-locations">Sniper Locations</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Strongholds">Strongholds</link></style> are all potential <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> features that can be placed in conjunction with the <style="CurrentLink">Arenas</style> to make them noticeable through the difference in gameplay they provide. <style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style> are quite often used to create the boundaries between <style="CurrentLink">Arenas</style> and other parts of the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. While not necessarily making them more noticeable, <style="Link"><link="check-points">Check Points</link></style> can be placed within <style="CurrentLink">Arenas</style> to draw gameplay to these areas and this can be used to balance the deterrent effect of <style="Link"><link="sniper-locations">Sniper Locations</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Arenas</style> focus where <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> takes place in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>. Controlling them can provide access to <style="Link"><link="check-points">Check Points</link></style> or other parts of the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and for this reason they are often <style="Link"><link="strategic-locations">Strategic Locations</link></style> and cause players to strive for <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style> of them. Given their openness, they make <style="Link"><link="herd">Herd</link></style> more difficult since that which is herded has more possibilities of heading of in the wrong directions. In <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>, they can let players coordinate attacks or defenses to achieve <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Arenas</style> provide natural starting points for considering adjacent <style="Link"><link="sniper-locations">Sniper Locations</link></style> and can in this way help instantiate these.
